headline: Green Party Co-Leader Suspended From Parliament Over 'Spineless' Comment
summary: Parliament was marked by procedural drama as Green Party Co-Leader Chlöe Swarbrick was suspended for refusing to apologize for calling government members 'spineless.' The day also saw heated debate over the Government's education reforms impacting Māori learners, and continued scrutiny of its economic management and infrastructure spending promises amid a rise in construction firm collapses.

topicSummaries.topic: Green Co-Leader Chlöe Swarbrick Suspended Over 'Spineless' Accusation
topicSummaries.content: A significant portion of the day was consumed by the suspension of Green Party Co-Leader Chlöe Swarbrick. The Speaker demanded she withdraw and apologise for calling government members 'spineless' during a debate the previous day. Swarbrick refused, leading to a vote to suspend her from the House. The move sparked a prolonged procedural debate, with Opposition Leader Chris Hipkins arguing it was an unprecedented action for a comment made on a previous day. The Speaker defended his decision, citing a need to raise the standard of debate and combat what he termed 'cyberbullying' in political discourse, a move that drew both criticism and support from various parties.

keyExchanges.speaker: SPEAKER
keyExchanges.quote: If you think about the comment that was made, 68 members of this House were accused of being spineless. There has never been a time when personal insults like that delivered inside a speech were accepted by this House, and I'm not about to start accepting it.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: I think the naming of a member for something they had done the day before is not something that has ever happened in the House before. I wonder whether you can reflect on what precedent or Standing Order you're relying on...

topicSummaries.topic: Heated Debate on Māori Education Reforms
topicSummaries.content: During Question Time, Te Pāti Māori MP Hana-Rawhiti Maipi-Clarke intensely questioned Education Minister Erica Stanford on the impact of proposed education changes on Māori learners. The exchange focused on the replacement of NCEA Level 1 with a Foundational Award and the alleged banning of Māori words from junior teaching resources. Minister Stanford defended the reforms, arguing they set higher aspirations for Māori students and that new te reo Māori phonics resources were being introduced. However, Maipi-Clarke voiced concerns from kura kaupapa providers that the Government was prioritising standardisation over cultural relevance, potentially disengaging Māori students.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hana-Rawhiti Maipi-Clarke (Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she agree with Te Rūnanga Nui o Ngā Kura Kaupapa Māori o Aotearoa that replacing NCEA level 1 with a Foundational Award in literacy and numeracy 'narrows the purpose of learning and risks disengaging students who benefit from a broader kaupapa Māori programme.'?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Erica Stanford (National)
keyExchanges.quote: A Foundational Award in literacy and numeracy and a whole year of learning through a deep curriculum to make sure that they go into Year 12 ready for learning for that first important year of national qualifications is going to set them up for success.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Faces Scrutiny Over Economic Management and Infrastructure Pipeline
topicSummaries.content: The Government's economic and fiscal management came under fire, with the Opposition linking rising interest rates and cuts to State house builds to 755 construction firm collapses in one year. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended his government's actions, blaming the previous administration's spending for high inflation and interest rates. He highlighted a $207 billion infrastructure pipeline, with $6 billion in projects slated to begin before Christmas, as evidence of his government's commitment to building and growth. However, he repeatedly deflected direct questions about whether infrastructure spending in 2026 would be higher or lower than in 2023.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why does he stand by his Government's decision to cut State house builds by 86 percent given construction leaders have stated that house construction is an anchor for the sector, and is that why 755 construction firms have collapsed in just one year under his leadership?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (National)
keyExchanges.quote: I'm actually proud that we've got an infrastructure pipeline now of $207 billion. I think we have $125 billion of projects under construction. We have announced another $6 billion of infrastructure projects to be built or commenced before Christmas.

topicSummaries.topic: Winston Peters Challenges Use of 'Aotearoa' in Parliament
topicSummaries.content: NZ First Leader Winston Peters raised a point of order questioning the use of the name 'Aotearoa' in an official parliamentary question, asking who had given the mandate to change the country's name. The Speaker defended its use, stating that as Māori is an official language, it is an acceptable name for Māori to use to identify the nation and has been for a long time. He advised Mr. Peters that the Standing Orders Committee was the appropriate venue to address the matter further, but reiterated that he had ruled on the issue twice and it should not be raised again.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Winston Peters (NZ First)
keyExchanges.quote: I want to know why question No. 1 has got a country imputably called 'Aotearoa', and who gave anybody the mandate to change this country's name?

keyExchanges.speaker: SPEAKER
keyExchanges.quote: The reality is that Māori is an official language of New Zealand. If that is a name that Māori choose to use to identify the nation, then that is an acceptable thing. It has been for a very long time...

conclusion: The day's proceedings were defined by a clash over parliamentary decorum and free speech, revealing deep tensions over political language, while substantive debates on education and the economy highlighted the Government's ongoing struggle to defend its reform agenda against accusations of cultural insensitivity and fiscal mismanagement.
